text: Resolution 2535 (2020)
Adopted by the Security Council at its 8748th meeting, on 14 July 2020
The Security Council,
Reaffirming its commitment to the full implementation of resolution 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018) and its Presidential Statement of 12 December 2019 (S/PRST/2019/15),
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* its commitment to the full implementation of resolution 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018) and its Presidential Statement of 12 December 2019 (S/PRST/2019/15),
uncertainties: References to resolutions and a presidential statement are documents, not entities from the provided list, so no mentioned entities were extracted.

text: Recalling its resolutions 1325 (2000), 1820 (2008), 1888 (2009), 1889 (2009), 1960 (2010), 2106 (2013), 2122 (2013), 2242 (2015), 2467 (2019) and 2493 (2019) on Women, Peace and Security and all relevant Statements of its President,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 1325 (2000), 1820 (2008), 1888 (2009), 1889 (2009), 1960 (2010), 2106 (2013), 2122 (2013), 2242 (2015), 2467 (2019) and 2493 (2019) on Women, Peace and Security and all relevant Statements of its President,

text: Recalling further its resolutions 1265 (1999), 1674 (2006) and 1894 (2009) on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling further* its resolutions 1265 (1999), 1674 (2006) and 1894 (2009) on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict,

text: Recalling its resolutions 1645 (2005), 2282 (2016) and 2413 (2018) on the peacebuilding architecture and the Statements of its President on Post-Conflict Peacebuilding S/PRST/2012/29 and S/PRST/2015/2 and on peacebuilding and sustaining peace S/PRST/2016/12,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 1645 (2005), 2282 (2016) and 2413 (2018) on the peacebuilding architecture and the Statements of its President on Post-Conflict Peacebuilding S/PRST/2012/29 and S/PRST/2015/2 and on peacebuilding and sustaining peace S/PRST/2016/12,
uncertainties: The phrase 'its President' refers to the President of the Security Council, which is not explicitly listed in the entity catalog; therefore no mentioned entity was added.

text: Recalling also its resolutions on Countering Terrorism including 2178 (2014), 2195 (2014), 2354 (2017), 2395 (2017), 2396 (2017), 2462 (2019) and 2482 (2019) and the Statement of its President S/PRST/2015/11, S/PRST/2020/5,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling also* its resolutions on Countering Terrorism including 2178 (2014), 2195 (2014), 2354 (2017), 2395 (2017), 2396 (2017), 2462 (2019) and 2482 (2019) and the Statement of its President S/PRST/2015/11, S/PRST/2020/5,

text: Reaffirming the importance of promoting the United Nations’ ability to deliver on its founding determination to save and support succeeding generations against the scourge of war and putting emphasis on preventive diplomacy, mediation and good offices, peacekeeping, peacebuilding, and sustaining peace,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the importance of promoting the {{United Nations’}} ability to deliver on its founding determination to save and support succeeding generations against the scourge of war and putting emphasis on preventive diplomacy, mediation and good offices, peacekeeping, peacebuilding, and sustaining peace,

text: Reaffirming the important and positive contribution youth can make to the efforts for the maintenance and promotion of peace and security, prevention and resolution of conflicts and as a key aspect of the sustainability, inclusiveness and success of peacekeeping and peace building efforts,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the important and positive contribution youth can make to the efforts for the maintenance and promotion of peace and security, prevention and resolution of conflicts and as a key aspect of the sustainability, inclusiveness and success of peacekeeping and peace building efforts,

text: Recognizing that today’s generation of youth is the largest the world has ever known and that young people often form the majority of the population of countries affected by armed conflict,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that today’s generation of youth is the largest the world has ever known and that young people often form the majority of the population of countries affected by armed conflict,

text: Noting that the term youth is defined in the context of this resolution as persons of the age of 18–29 years old, and further noting the variations of definition of the term that may exist on the national and international levels, including the definition of youth in the General Assembly Resolutions A/RES/50/81 and A/RES/56/117,
textWithHighlights: *Noting* that the term youth is defined in the context of this resolution as persons of the age of 18–29 years old, and *further noting* the variations of definition of the term that may exist on the national and international levels, including the definition of youth in the {{General Assembly}} Resolutions A/RES/50/81 and A/RES/56/117,

text: Bearing in mind the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and the primary responsibility of the Security Council under the Charter for the maintenance of international peace and security,
textWithHighlights: *Bearing in mind* the purposes and principles of the Charter of the {{United Nations}} and the primary responsibility of the {{Security Council}} under the Charter for the maintenance of international peace and security,

text: Expressing concern that among civilians, youth account for many of those adversely affected by armed conflict, including as refugees and internally displaced persons, and that the disruption of youth’s access to quality education and economic opportunities has a dramatic impact on durable peace and reconciliation,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing concern* that among civilians, youth account for many of those adversely affected by armed conflict, including as refugees and internally displaced persons, and that the disruption of youth’s access to quality education and economic opportunities has a dramatic impact on durable peace and reconciliation,

text: Recognizing that youth should actively be engaged in shaping lasting peace and contributing to justice and reconciliation, and that a large youth population presents a unique demographic dividend that can contribute to lasting peace and economic prosperity if inclusive policies are in place,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that youth should actively be engaged in shaping lasting peace and contributing to justice and reconciliation, and that a large youth population presents a unique demographic dividend that can contribute to lasting peace and economic prosperity if inclusive policies are in place,

text: Recognizing that the protection of all youth, particularly young women, refugees and internally displaced youth in armed conflict and post-conflict and their participation in peace processes can significantly contribute to the maintenance and promotion of international peace and security, and should be an important component of any comprehensive strategy to resolve conflict and build peace,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that the protection of all youth, particularly young women, refugees and internally displaced youth in armed conflict and post-conflict and their participation in peace processes can significantly contribute to the maintenance and promotion of international peace and security, and should be an important component of any comprehensive strategy to resolve conflict and build peace,

text: Emphasizing the importance of a comprehensive approach to peacebuilding and sustaining peace, particularly through the prevention of conflict and addressing its root causes at all stages of conflict,
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizing* the importance of a comprehensive approach to peacebuilding and sustaining peace, particularly through the prevention of conflict and addressing its root causes at all stages of conflict,

text: Reaffirming the primary responsibility of national governments and authorities in identifying, driving and directing priorities, strategies and activities for peacebuilding and sustaining peace and that inclusivity, including by ensuring full, effective and meaningful participation of youth without discrimination of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, disability, religion or belief, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status is key to advancing peacebuilding processes and objectives in order to ensure that the needs of all segments of society are taken into account,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the primary responsibility of {{national governments and authorities}} in identifying, driving and directing priorities, strategies and activities for peacebuilding and sustaining peace and that inclusivity, including by ensuring full, effective and meaningful participation of youth without discrimination of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, disability, religion or belief, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status is key to advancing peacebuilding processes and objectives in order to ensure that the needs of all segments of society are taken into account,
uncertainties: Normalized 'national governments and authorities' to 'Member States' as a mentioned entity; no assignees or deliverables since this is a preambular (reinforcing) paragraph.

text: Reiterating the important role youth can play as agents of change in countering terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism,
textWithHighlights: *Reiterating* the important role youth can play as agents of change in countering terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism,

text: Recognizing that core challenges still remain, including structural barriers that limit the participation and capacity of young people, especially young women, to influence decision making, violations of their human rights, and insufficient investment in facilitating inclusion, particularly through quality education,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that core challenges still remain, including structural barriers that limit the participation and capacity of young people, especially young women, to influence decision making, violations of their human rights, and insufficient investment in facilitating inclusion, particularly through quality education,

text: Recognizing the significance of the fifth anniversary of resolution 2250 (2015), the twentieth anniversary of resolution 1325 (2000),the review of the United Nations peacebuilding architecture, the launch of the Decade of Action and delivery for Sustainable Development, the 25th anniversary of the Platform for Action of the Fourth World Conference on Women and the seventy fifth anniversary of the United Nations, and the 5th anniversary since the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals offering a prime opportunity to highlight the invaluable role of young people and to amplify their voices and perspectives in shaping the world and its future,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the significance of the fifth anniversary of resolution 2250 (2015), the twentieth anniversary of resolution 1325 (2000),the review of the {{United Nations}} peacebuilding architecture, the launch of the Decade of Action and delivery for Sustainable Development, the 25th anniversary of the Platform for Action of the Fourth World Conference on Women and the seventy fifth anniversary of the {{United Nations}}, and the 5th anniversary since the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals offering a prime opportunity to highlight the invaluable role of young people and to amplify their voices and perspectives in shaping the world and its future,

text: Acknowledging the on-going work of national governments and regional and international organisations to engage youth in building and maintaining peace,
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledging* the on-going work of {{national governments}} and {{regional}} and {{international organisations}} to engage youth in building and maintaining peace,

text: Recognizing the importance of civil society, including community-based civil society, youth, women, peacebuilders, and where relevant the private sector, academia, think tanks, media, and cultural, educational, and religious leaders in peace building efforts and sustaining peace, including by increasing awareness about threats of terrorism and more effectively tackling them,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the importance of {{civil society}}, including {{community-based civil society}}, {{youth}}, {{women}}, {{peacebuilders}}, and where relevant the {{private sector}}, {{academia}}, {{think tanks}}, {{media}}, and {{cultural, educational, and religious leaders}} in peace building efforts and sustaining peace, including by increasing awareness about threats of terrorism and more effectively tackling them,

text: Taking note with appreciation of the United Nations Youth 2030 Strategy of the Secretary-General which provides a road map for the United Nations system, including a specific priority on peacebuilding and resilience-building, directly aligned with resolutions 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018),
textWithHighlights: *Taking note with appreciation* of the United Nations Youth 2030 Strategy of the {{Secretary-General}} which provides a road map for the {{United Nations system}}, including a specific priority on peacebuilding and resilience-building, directly aligned with resolutions 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018),

text: Recognizing the challenges faced by youth, especially by young women, which put them at particular risk, including gender inequalities that perpetuate all forms of discrimination and violence and emphasizing that advancing gender equality and empowerment of women is critical for the full, equal and effective participation of women at all stages of peace processes given their vital role in the prevention and resolution of conflict and peacebuilding, reaffirming the key role women can play in re-establishing the fabric of recovering society and in the development and implementation of post-conflict strategies in order to take into account their perspectives and needs,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the challenges faced by youth, especially by young women, which put them at particular risk, including gender inequalities that perpetuate all forms of discrimination and violence and *emphasizing* that advancing gender equality and empowerment of women is critical for the full, equal and effective participation of women at all stages of peace processes given their vital role in the prevention and resolution of conflict and peacebuilding, *reaffirming* the key role women can play in re-establishing the fabric of recovering society and in the development and implementation of post-conflict strategies in order to take into account their perspectives and needs,

text: Reaffirming the right to education and its contribution to the achievement of peace and security and further recognizing that investment in universal, and inclusive education and training is an important policy investment that States can make to ensure the immediate and long-term development of youth, and reiterating that access to inclusive, equitable and quality formal and non-formal education are important factors that enable youth to acquire the relevant skills and to build their capacities,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the right to education and its contribution to the achievement of peace and security and *further recognizing* that investment in universal, and inclusive education and training is an important policy investment that {{States}} can make to ensure the immediate and long-term development of youth, and *reiterating* that access to inclusive, equitable and quality formal and non-formal education are important factors that enable youth to acquire the relevant skills and to build their capacities,
uncertainties: "States" is assumed to refer to Member States.

text: Taking note of the first report of the Secretary-General of 2 March 2020 (S/2020/167) and its recommendations, and noting the independent Progress Study on Youth, Peace and Security, “The missing peace”,
textWithHighlights: *Taking note* of the first report of the {{Secretary-General}} of 2 March 2020 (S/2020/167) and its recommendations, and *noting* the independent Progress Study on Youth, Peace and Security, “The missing peace”,

text: Calls on all relevant actors, to consider ways to increase the inclusive representation of youth for the prevention and resolution of conflict, as well as in peacebuilding, including when negotiating and implementing peace agreements, and to ensure the full, effective and meaningful participation of youth, recognizing that their marginalization is detrimental to building sustainable peace;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Increase representation of youth in peace processes
deliverables.deliverable: increase the inclusive representation of youth

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ensure participation of youth in peace processes
deliverables.deliverable: ensure the full, effective and meaningful participation of youth

textWithHighlights: *Calls on* all relevant actors, to consider ways to [[increase the inclusive representation of youth]] for the prevention and resolution of conflict, as well as in peacebuilding, including when negotiating and implementing peace agreements, and to [[ensure the full, effective and meaningful participation of youth]], recognizing that their marginalization is detrimental to building sustainable peace;
uncertainties: "All relevant actors" is not a concrete assignee, so no assignee recorded. Deliverables interpreted as policy aims (inclusion/participation) despite aspirational framing.

text: Reaffirms states’ obligation to respect, promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms of all individuals, including youth, and ensure equal access to justice and preserve the integrity of rule of law institutions; and to foster an enabling and safe environment for youth working on peace and security, including by protecting civic and political space and condemning hate speech and incitement to violence;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* <<states’>> obligation to respect, promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms of all individuals, including youth, and ensure equal access to justice and preserve the integrity of rule of law institutions; and to foster an enabling and safe environment for youth working on peace and security, including by protecting civic and political space and condemning hate speech and incitement to violence;
uncertainties: "states’" is interpreted as UN Member States.

text: Urges all parties to armed conflict to protect civilians, including those who are youth, and to comply strictly with their obligations under international law, inter alia under the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and the Additional Protocols thereto of 1977;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Protection of civilians
Compliance with international law

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<all parties to armed conflict>> to [[protect civilians]], including those who are youth, and to [[comply strictly]] with their obligations under international law, inter alia under the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and the Additional Protocols thereto of 1977;
uncertainties: Mapped 'protect civilians' to deliverable type 'policy' and 'comply strictly with their obligations under international law' to 'standards'; other classifications could be considered.

text: Further urges Member States to protect youth from violence in armed conflict, and urges all parties to eliminate all forms of sexual and gender-based violence as well as human trafficking;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Protection of youth from violence in armed conflict
Elimination of sexual and gender-based violence and human trafficking
deliverables.deliverable: eliminate all forms of sexual and gender-based violence as well as human trafficking

textWithHighlights: Further *urges* <<Member States>> to [[protect youth]] from violence in armed conflict, and *urges* <<all parties>> to [[eliminate all forms of sexual and gender-based violence as well as human trafficking]];
uncertainties: The assignee "all parties" likely refers to parties to armed conflict; categorized as 'other'. Deliverable types are approximated as 'humanitarian_assistance' since actions involve protection/elimination of violence rather than policy-making.

text: Urges Member States to facilitate an inclusive, safe, enabling and gender-responsive environment in which youth actors, including youth from different backgrounds are recognized and provided with adequate support and protection to implement violence prevention activities and support social cohesion, and to carry out their work independently and without undue interference, including in situations of armed conflict, and to investigate thoroughly and impartially threats, harassment, and violence against them, to ensure that perpetrators be brought to justice;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Enabling and gender-responsive environment for youth actors
Investigations into threats, harassment and violence against youth actors
Bring perpetrators to justice

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>> to facilitate an inclusive, safe, [[enabling and gender-responsive environment]] in which youth actors, including youth from different backgrounds are recognized and provided with adequate support and protection to implement violence prevention activities and support social cohesion, and to carry out their work independently and without undue interference, including in situations of armed conflict, and to [[investigate]] thoroughly and impartially threats, harassment, and violence against them, to ensure that perpetrators be [[brought to justice]];
uncertainties: 'Brought to justice' is a concrete action but does not map neatly to the deliverable type list; classified here as 'policy'. The clause about providing 'adequate support and protection' for youth actors is embedded within the enabling environment; it could be read as a separate task (capacity building/protection), but was not extracted separately to stay conservative.

text: Also calls upon Member States to comply with their respective obligations to end impunity and further calls on them to investigate and prosecute those responsible for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and other egregious crimes perpetrated against civilians, including youth;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: investigation and prosecution of perpetrators of atrocity crimes

textWithHighlights: Also *calls upon* <<Member States>> to comply with their respective obligations to end impunity and further *calls on* <<them>> to [[investigate and prosecute]] those responsible for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and other egregious crimes perpetrated against civilians, including youth;
uncertainties: Classifying “prosecute” under a deliverable type is not a perfect fit; grouped with “investigate” and mapped to “analysis” as the closest available category.

text: Stresses the importance of providing opportunities for young people to strengthen resilience against radicalization to violence and terrorist recruitment by creating policies for youth, while complying with relevant obligations under international law, in particular international human rights law and international humanitarian law as an essential part of successful counter-terrorism efforts;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* the importance of providing opportunities for young people to strengthen resilience against radicalization to violence and terrorist recruitment by creating policies for youth, while complying with relevant obligations under international law, in particular international human rights law and international humanitarian law as an essential part of successful counter-terrorism efforts;

text: Stresses the importance of creating policies for youth that would positively contribute to peacebuilding efforts, including social and economic development, supporting projects designed to grow local economies, and provide youth employment opportunities and vocational training, fostering their education, and promoting youth entrepreneurship and constructive political engagement;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* the importance of creating policies for youth that would positively contribute to peacebuilding efforts, including social and economic development, supporting projects designed to grow local economies, and provide youth employment opportunities and vocational training, fostering their education, and promoting youth entrepreneurship and constructive political engagement;

text: Recognizes that digital spaces provide innovative participation opportunities for dialogue, accountability and transparency in decision-making, including in conflict-affected contexts and that, at the same time, inequalities with regards to access to technology remain widespread and Internet and social media can be used to spread disinformation and terrorist ideologies and threaten and attack young activists and expressing concern over the increased use, in a globalized society, by terrorists and their supporters of new information and communication technologies for terrorist purposes, and encourages Member States to act cooperatively to prevent terrorists from exploiting technology, communications and resources for terrorist acts, while respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms and in compliance with other obligations under international law;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that digital spaces provide innovative participation opportunities for dialogue, accountability and transparency in decision-making, including in conflict-affected contexts and that, at the same time, inequalities with regards to access to technology remain widespread and Internet and social media can be used to spread disinformation and terrorist ideologies and threaten and attack young activists and expressing concern over the increased use, in a globalized society, by terrorists and their supporters of new information and communication technologies for terrorist purposes, and *encourages* <<Member States>> to act cooperatively to prevent terrorists from exploiting technology, communications and resources for terrorist acts, while respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms and in compliance with other obligations under international law;

text: Recognizes that young people’s meaningful engagement in humanitarian planning and response is essential to improve the effectiveness of humanitarian assistance and that young people play a unique role in strengthening the national, local and community-based capacities in conflict and post-conflict situations to prepare for and respond to increasingly frequent and severe weather events and natural disasters, as well as to public health challenges that affect young people’s life and their future, including the COVID-19 pandemic, and in this regard, encourages member states to support and integrate youth into decision-making processes in these regards;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Integration of youth into decision-making

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that young people’s meaningful engagement in humanitarian planning and response is essential to improve the effectiveness of humanitarian assistance and that young people play a unique role in strengthening the national, local and community-based capacities in conflict and post-conflict situations to prepare for and respond to increasingly frequent and severe weather events and natural disasters, as well as to public health challenges that affect young people’s life and their future, including the COVID-19 pandemic, and in this regard, *encourages* <<member states>> to support and [[integrate youth into decision-making processes]] in these regards;
uncertainties: Considered whether 'support' constitutes a concrete deliverable; treated only 'integrate youth into decision-making processes' as a policy deliverable.

text: Calls on Member States to take appropriate measures to promote the physical and psychological recovery and social reintegration of young survivors of armed conflict, including those with disabilities, and survivors of sexual violence in conflict by providing, amongst others, access to quality education, socio-economic support and skills development such as vocational training, to resume social and economic life;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Access to quality education
Socio-economic support
Vocational training

textWithHighlights: *Calls on* <<Member States>> to take appropriate measures to promote the physical and psychological recovery and social reintegration of young survivors of armed conflict, including those with disabilities, and survivors of sexual violence in conflict by providing, amongst others, [[access to quality education]], [[socio-economic support]] and skills development such as [[vocational training]], to resume social and economic life;
uncertainties: Mapped 'socio-economic support' to humanitarian_assistance; could alternatively be considered financial_resources depending on implementation details. 'Access to quality education' is mapped to capacity_building due to its training/skills dimension.

text: Calls upon Member States to protect educational institutions as spaces free from all forms of violence, and to ensure that they are accessible to all youth, including marginalized youth, and take steps to address young women’s equal enjoyment of their right to education;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Protect educational institutions
Ensure accessibility for all youth
Address young women's equal enjoyment of the right to education

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<Member States>> to [[protect educational institutions]] as spaces free from all forms of violence, and to ensure that they are [[accessible to all youth]], including marginalized youth, and take steps to address [[young women’s equal enjoyment]] of their right to education;
uncertainties: Classified deliverables as 'policy' though actions could involve various measures beyond formal policies.

text: Calls on Member states to take steps to encourage the meaningful participation of youth in the reconstruction of areas devastated by conflict, to bring help to refugees, internally displaced persons, and war victims and promote peace, reconciliation and rehabilitation;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Humanitarian assistance to refugees, internally displaced persons and war victims
deliverables.deliverable: help to refugees, internally displaced persons, and war victims

textWithHighlights: *Calls on* <<Member states>> to take steps to encourage the meaningful participation of youth in the reconstruction of areas devastated by conflict, to bring [[help to refugees, internally displaced persons, and war victims]] and promote peace, reconciliation and rehabilitation;
uncertainties: Considered but excluded as deliverables due to vagueness: encouraging youth participation in reconstruction and promoting peace, reconciliation and rehabilitation. 'Reconstruction' itself is referenced but not directly tasked; the concrete task identified is bringing help (humanitarian assistance).

text: Encourages Member States, regional and subregional organizations to develop and implement policies and programs for youth and to facilitate their constructive engagement, including through dedicated local, national and regional roadmaps on youth, peace and security, with sufficient resources, through a participatory process, in particular with young people and youth organizations and to pursue its implementation, including through the monitoring, evaluation and coordination with young people;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: policies and programmes for youth
roadmaps on youth, peace and security
monitoring and evaluation

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, <<regional>> and <<subregional organizations>> to develop and implement [[policies and programs]] for youth and to facilitate their constructive engagement, including through dedicated local, national and regional [[roadmaps]] on youth, peace and security, with sufficient resources, through a participatory process, in particular with young people and youth organizations and to pursue its implementation, including through the [[monitoring, evaluation]] and coordination with young people;
uncertainties: Classified “programs” under the deliverable type “policy” due to the lack of a dedicated “programmes” category. Split “regional and subregional organizations” into two assignees; highlighted “regional” alone per guideline example where the shared noun is elided.

text: Welcomes the efforts of the Peacebuilding Commission to advance the youth, peace and security agenda and its increased engagement in support of young peacebuilders and include in its discussions and advice, ways to engage youth meaningfully in national, regional and international efforts to build and sustain peace, while reaffirming its principle of national ownership and leadership in peacebuilding, and encourages the Peacebuilding Commission to continue to support the important peacebuilding role that young people play and the participation and views of youth-led organization, in planning and stabilization efforts in peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and to continue to bring its observations and advice to the attention of the Security Council, as appropriate;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Observations and advice to Security Council

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the efforts of the {{Peacebuilding Commission}} to advance the youth, peace and security agenda and its increased engagement in support of young peacebuilders and include in its discussions and advice, ways to engage youth meaningfully in national, regional and international efforts to build and sustain peace, while reaffirming its principle of national ownership and leadership in peacebuilding, and *encourages* the <<Peacebuilding Commission>> to continue to support the important peacebuilding role that young people play and the participation and views of youth-led organization, in planning and stabilization efforts in peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and to continue to bring its [[observations and advice]] to the attention of the {{Security Council}}, as appropriate;
uncertainties: Peacebuilding Commission is not listed explicitly in the provided entity list; classified as type "other" with normalized name "Peacebuilding Commission". The deliverable "observations and advice" could arguably be categorized as a report rather than a briefing; chosen as "briefing" given the phrasing "bring to the attention".

text: Calls on Member States, regional organizations and the United Nations system, including peacekeeping and special political missions, to coordinate and increase their engagement in the implementation of resolutions 2250 (2015), 2419 (2018), and this resolution including through inclusive partnership with young people, and to ensure dedicated capacities with regard to youth, peace and security, and in this regard encourages the Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Youth to promote coordination and coherence of youth, peace and security activities across the UN-system while tracking implementation of this resolution as well as resolutions 2250 and 2419;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Dedicated capacities for youth, peace and security

assignees.assignee: Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Youth

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Tracking implementation of this resolution and resolutions 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018)

textWithHighlights: *Calls on* <<Member States>>, <<regional organizations>> and the <<United Nations system>>, including peacekeeping and special political missions, to coordinate and increase their engagement in the implementation of resolutions 2250 (2015), 2419 (2018), and this resolution including through inclusive partnership with young people, and to ensure [[dedicated capacities]] with regard to youth, peace and security, and in this regard *encourages* the <<Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Youth>> to promote coordination and coherence of youth, peace and security activities across the {{UN-system}} while [[tracking implementation]] of this resolution as well as resolutions 2250 and 2419;
uncertainties: Mapped the Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Youth to UNYO (United Nations Youth Office) for normalization; if treated as a separate office, a different normalized label might be preferred. Considered only “dedicated capacities” and “tracking implementation” as concrete deliverables; other elements (coordination, increased engagement, partnerships) were treated as too vague to classify as deliverables.

text: Encourages Member States to consider increasing, as appropriate, funding for the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda, including accessible resourcing for youth-led and youth-focused organizations;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Funding for youth, peace and security agenda
Accessible resourcing for youth-led and youth-focused organizations

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>> to consider increasing, as appropriate, [[funding]] for the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda, including [[accessible resourcing]] for {{youth-led and youth-focused organizations}};

text: Expresses its intention, where appropriate, to continue to invite civil society including youth-led organizations as well as young peacebuilders to brief the Council in country-specific considerations and relevant thematic areas and include interactive and inclusive meetings with local youth, youth-led organizations and young peacebuilders, in the field during Council missions;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Briefing to the Security Council
Meetings with youth during Council missions

textWithHighlights: *Expresses its intention*, where appropriate, to continue to invite {{civil society}} including {{youth-led organizations}} as well as {{young peacebuilders}} to [[brief the Council]] in country-specific considerations and relevant thematic areas and include [[interactive and inclusive meetings]] with {{local youth}}, {{youth-led organizations}} and {{young peacebuilders}}, in the field during {{Council}} missions;

text: Recognizes the role of the Secretary General’s Envoy on Youth and her Office, and the work of relevant entities of the United Nations, Rapporteurs, Special Envoys, Representatives of the Secretary-General, and Resident Coordinators in the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda, in line with the five pillars outlined by resolution 2250, which are participation, protection, prevention, disengagement and reintegration, and partnerships, including by ensuring that the essential role of young people in advancing peace and security is fully recognized and supported and encourages them to continue improving their coordination and interaction regarding the role and the needs of youth during armed conflicts and post-conflict situations, including with regional organizations;

assignees.assignee: Secretary General’s Envoy on Youth and her Office
relevant entities of the United Nations

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Improve coordination and interaction on youth needs in conflicts and post-conflict situations

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the role of the <<Secretary General’s Envoy on Youth and her Office>>, and the work of <<relevant entities of the United Nations>>, <<Rapporteurs>>, <<Special Envoys>>, <<Representatives of the Secretary-General>>, and <<Resident Coordinators>> in the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda, in line with the five pillars outlined by resolution 2250, which are participation, protection, prevention, disengagement and reintegration, and partnerships, including by ensuring that the essential role of young people in advancing peace and security is fully recognized and supported and *encourages* them to continue improving their [[coordination and interaction]] regarding the role and the needs of youth during armed conflicts and post-conflict situations, including with {{regional organizations}};
uncertainties: Generic roles (Rapporteurs, Special Envoys, SRSGs) are not explicitly listed entities; normalized as concrete but categorized as 'other'. The Envoy on Youth is mapped to UNYO (new UN Youth Office). Deliverable type chosen as information_sharing for coordination/interaction; could also be seen as meetings.

text: Requests the Secretary-General and his Special Envoys to include the views of youth in relevant discussions pertinent to the maintenance of peace and security, peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and to facilitate the full, effective and meaningful participation of youth at all decision-making levels, paying particular attention to the inclusion of young women and without distinction or discrimination of any kind;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Include youth views in peace and security discussions
Facilitate youth participation in decision-making

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> and his <<Special Envoys>> to [[include the views of youth]] in relevant discussions pertinent to the maintenance of peace and security, peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and to facilitate the full, effective and meaningful [[participation of youth]] at all decision-making levels, paying particular attention to the inclusion of young women and without distinction or discrimination of any kind;
uncertainties: "Special Envoys" is a generic reference; normalized as "UN Special Envoys" under UN Secretariat. Deliverable types are approximations: inclusion of youth views categorized as information_sharing; facilitating youth participation categorized as meeting.

text: Requests the Secretary General to provide guidance for all peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions on the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda and urges all peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions to develop and implement context-specific strategies on youth, peace and security, bearing in mind their respective mandates;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Guidance on implementing the youth, peace and security agenda for missions

assignees.assignee: peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Context-specific strategies on youth, peace and security

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary General>> to provide [[guidance]] for all peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions on the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda and *urges* all <<peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions>> to develop and implement [[context-specific strategies]] on youth, peace and security, bearing in mind their respective mandates;
uncertainties: Normalized assignee name for 'peacekeeping and other relevant United Nations missions' is not in the provided entity list; treated as 'UN peacekeeping and other missions' under UN Secretariat.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to develop a dedicated guidance on the protection of young people, including those who engage with the United Nations in the context of peace and security and as part of the new Common Agenda on Protection for the UN System;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Guidance on protection of young people

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to develop a [[dedicated guidance]] on the protection of young people, including those who engage with the {{United Nations}} in the context of peace and security and as part of the new Common Agenda on Protection for the {{UN System}};
uncertainties: Classified “guidance” under deliverable type “policy”; could also be seen as “standards” depending on interpretation.

text: Encourages the Secretary-General and relevant United Nations Entities, to develop internal mechanisms within the United Nations system to broaden the participation of youth, within the work of the United Nations and to redouble their efforts to improve capacity building and technical guidance and to integrate the youth, peace and security agenda in United Nations strategic and planning documents, conflict analyses, frameworks, initiatives and guidance tools, at the global, regional and national levels, including by appointing youth focal points, building on existing human resources, for the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda within their respective mandates;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: internal mechanisms to broaden youth participation
capacity building
technical guidance
integration of the youth, peace and security agenda
deliverables.deliverable: integrate the youth, peace and security agenda

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: appoint youth focal points

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* the <<Secretary-General>> and <<relevant United Nations Entities>>, to develop [[internal mechanisms]] within the {{United Nations system}} to broaden the participation of youth, within the work of the United Nations and to redouble their efforts to improve [[capacity building]] and [[technical guidance]] and to [[integrate the youth, peace and security agenda]] in United Nations strategic and planning documents, conflict analyses, frameworks, initiatives and guidance tools, at the global, regional and national levels, including by appointing [[youth focal points]], building on existing human resources, for the implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda within their respective mandates;
uncertainties: Classified “internal mechanisms” and “youth focal points” under policy due to institutional/organizational nature; mapped “relevant United Nations Entities” to UN System as the closest standardized entity.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to include information and related recommendations on issues of relevance to young people, in the context of armed conflict, including on progress made towards participation of youth in peace processes, in thematic and geographic reports and regular briefings to the Council, as well as to include pertinent disaggregated data related to youth within existing mandates;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: recommendations on issues relevant to youth in armed conflict
thematic and geographic reports
regular briefings to the Security Council
pertinent disaggregated data related to youth

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to include information and [[related recommendations]] on issues of relevance to young people, in the context of armed conflict, including on progress made towards participation of youth in peace processes, in [[thematic and geographic reports]] and [[regular briefings]] to the {{Council}}, as well as to include pertinent [[disaggregated data]] related to youth within existing mandates;
uncertainties: Classifying “disaggregated data” as analysis; it could also be seen as information sharing. The task emphasizes inclusion within existing outputs rather than creating new ones, but reports/briefings are still treated as deliverables.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to ensure that, within existing resources, capacities and expertise to engage young people and youth organizations in peacebuilding and sustaining peace at the local, national, regional and international levels and programmatic activities are in place for the accelerated implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Capacities and expertise to engage youth in peacebuilding
Programmatic activities for implementing youth, peace and security agenda

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to ensure that, within existing resources, [[capacities and expertise]] to engage young people and youth organizations in peacebuilding and sustaining peace at the local, national, regional and international levels and [[programmatic activities]] are in place for the accelerated implementation of the youth, peace and security agenda;
uncertainties: "Programmatic activities" do not map cleanly to a deliverable category; classified under "strategy" as coordinated initiatives. The clause structure suggests ensuring both capacities/experts and programmatic activities are in place; treated both as deliverables.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to submit a biennial report to the Security Council on the implementation of this resolution and of resolutions 2250 and 2419;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Biennial report on implementation of this resolution and resolutions 2250 and 2419

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to submit a [[biennial report]] to the {{Security Council}} on the implementation of this resolution and of resolutions 2250 and 2419;

text: Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
textWithHighlights: *Decides* to remain actively seized of the matter.
